Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Low Temperature Microplasmas For Thermal Energy Conversion, Education, and Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER Abstract:
Low Temperature Microplasmas For Thermal Energy Conversion, Education, and Outreach

Thermionic energy conversion (TEC) is the direct conversion of heat to electricity by the thermal
(thermionic) emission of electrons from a very hot surface. Though historically pursued primarily
for electricity production from nuclear sources in space applications, it has the potential to be used
terrestrially for waste heat, solar, or nuclear energy conversion. To meet this objective, however,
TEC must be enhanced to operate more efficiently at lower temperatures than historically possible.
Microplasma thermionic energy conversion occurs when a microplasma (ionized gas) is ignited
between a thermionic diode with an electrode spacing ~1-20 micrometers. This mode of operation
could enable operation in inert gases, at near atmospheric pressures, and at lower temperatures - all
necessary features for practical terrestrial application. Understanding of the fundamental interaction
between thermionic emission and microplasmas will be advanced by this research in order to pave
the way for microplasma-TEC devices. First principles theory and simulations will be used to reveal
the inter-dependence between a microplasma and thermionic emission, and experiments will be
conducted to confirm the enhancement of thermionic emission by a microplasma necessary to realize
improved energy conversion efficiency. Carbon-based electrodes, including diamond and carbon
nanotubes, will be synthesized using a microplasma jet processing technique and used as electrodes
in microplasma-TEC experiments. In addition to the efficacy of microplasma-TEC being established
by this research, fundamental studies will also advance the basic understanding of plasma/electrode
coupling, where there are persistent questions that affect a wide variety of technologies from highintensity
discharge lamps to arc-based materials deposition.

Direct thermal-to-electrical energy conversion can be used to convert solar, nuclear, and waste heat
to electricity, and energy conversion technologies will play an important role in creating a more
energy efficient and independent nation. The discoveries made by this research will lay the
foundation for practical, terrestrial TEC devices that could become an essential part of the energy
economy, greatly impacting energy security in the United States. Further, undergraduate students
from underrepresented minorities will be engaged in this research early in their careers, creating a
more effective undergraduate research experience and increasing the number that achieve graduate
science and engineering degrees. Using a service-learning approach, outreach to the local K-8 youth
in the community will be led by these undergraduates including the creation of a plasma exhibit for a
community-wide science festival and a targeted, interactive outreach program on environmental
science for middle school students. These undergraduate students will be exposed to the fulfilling
nature of outreach and also inspire a large number of K-8 youth toward science and engineering,
creating a perpetuating educational cycle in which each generation fosters the inspiration,
excitement, and development of the next generation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the team explored how to use microscale phenomena to enhance plasma formation and how to create devices to benefit from this interaction. Specifically, the role of electron emission, either due to heat (thermionic) or extremely high electric fields (field), on microplasma formation and subsequent properties was studied. The team found that under high temperature conditions, thermionic emission and the microplasma can couple with each other to increase thermal-to-electrical energy production. However, there are virtually no conditions where this can be achieved efficiently. Instead, the team focused on how electron emission could be used to create favorable chemical conditions in microplasmas. The team found that at the microscale, field emission produced electrons that could be tuned to have specific energies by controlling the voltage, pressure, and size of the device. Electrons interact with gas particles, and these interactions drive chemical reactions. For example, in carbon dioxide, it has been shown that electrons can vibrationally excite CO2 in two ways – asymmetrically or symmetrically,.  Importantly, asymmetric excitation can lead to more effective CO2 dissociation, removing this harmful pollutant and allowing it to be recycled into other useful chemicals (such as synthetic gas). Our team used modeling to show that the conditions of a field emission microplasma can be tuned to favor asymmetric excitation over not only symmetric excitation, but all other electron-driven chemical reactions. Potential conditions to produce such favored excitation were determined.

 

In complementary work, the team explored how plasmas can more effectively synthesize ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen when passed through a packed bed catalyst reactor. Collaborators showed that with the proper selection of a catalyst material, ammonia can be produced more effectively at atmospheric pressure with a dielectric barrier discharge than with no plasma. Our team showed that the catalyst material packed into the reactor does not actually affect the properties of the plasma, which was a major concern. Since the plasma itself is not affected, the team’s findings support the conjecture that the enhanced chemical performance is due to the unique surface interaction between the plasma and catalyst material itself. This insight is crucial for developing more effective catalysts that interact with plasmas for this and other chemical applications.

 

The team also had the aim of helping develop the next generation of scientists and engineers by engaging undergraduates in sustained research opportunities, participating in a K-12 science exhibition, and coordinating research between local high school students from Trinity School at Greenlawn and Notre Dame research groups. In addition to an annual plasma science table at Science Alive, which was highlighted in a photograph in the local newspaper, three undergraduate researchers, including one from an underrepresented group, participated as co-authors on journal publications and over 20 high school students participated in research projects at Notre Dame. Two of those high school students, who worked directly with the PI, progressed from the local science and engineering fair to the 2018 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair, where they won a special recognition from the Coalition for Plasma Science. Both students, one young woman and one young man, will be starting at universities in the Fall of 2019.
